conclusion: The working principle of the electromagnetic railgun involves a projectile moving freely between two parallel rails, maintaining good contact with the rails. Current flows in from one rail, passes through the conductive projectile, and flows back through the other rail. The rail current generates a magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the rails at the projectile, which can be considered a uniform magnetic field. The electrified projectile is propelled at high speed along the rails due to the Lorentz force acting on it.

Xiao Ming purchased a railgun model online, with a rail length of L = 0.5 m, a parallel rail spacing of d = 0.02 m, a projectile mass of m = 0.02 kg, a rail current of I = 10 A, and a magnetic field strength of B = 1 T. All resistances are neglected.

premise: The conductor that actually feels the magnetic force is the bar that bridges the two rails; its length in the field is the rail spacing d.
conclusion: Force on the conductive projectile F = I d B = (10 A)(0.02 m)(1 T) = 0.20 N

premise: Force on the conductive projectile F = 0.20 N and projectile mass m = 0.02 kg.
conclusion: Acceleration of the projectile a = F/m = 0.20 N / 0.020 kg = 10 m s⁻²

premise: The projectile starts from rest and travels the 0.50 m rail length L under constant acceleration a = 10 m s⁻².
conclusion: Exit velocity v² = 2aL = 2(10 m s⁻²)(0.50 m) = 10 → v = √10 ≈ 3.16 m s⁻¹

premise: Exit velocity v = √10 m s⁻¹ and projectile mass m = 0.02 kg.
conclusion: Kinetic energy at the muzzle E_k = ½ m v² = ½(0.020 kg)(10 m² s⁻²) = 0.10 J

premise: Rail length L = 0.50 m and acceleration a = 10 m s⁻².
conclusion: Time the projectile is in the barrel t = √(2L/a) = √(1) = 1 s

premise: Kinetic energy at the muzzle E_k = 0.10 J and time t = 1 s.
conclusion: Average electrical-to-mechanical power over the shot P_avg = E_k / t = 0.10 J / 1 s = 0.10 W

premise: Force on the conductive projectile F = 0.20 N and exit velocity v = √10 m s⁻¹.
conclusion: Instantaneous mechanical power at the muzzle P_exit = F v = (0.20 N)(3.16 m s⁻¹) ≈ 0.63 W

premise: Average electrical-to-mechanical power over the shot P_avg = 0.10 W and instantaneous mechanical power at the muzzle P_exit ≈ 0.63 W.
conclusion: When the projectile leaves the 0.5-m rails, its kinetic energy is 0.10 J. This corresponds to an average launch power of about 0.10 W, while the instantaneous mechanical power at the muzzle is roughly 0.6 W.
